author: sky.cactus
content: I think the thing we need to do a better job explaining to people is that no wallet should be allowing users to sign arbitrary 3074 transactions.  When people say, "user can now sign a transaction that gives away all of their money" I believe that they are assuming that wallets will forward 3074 signing requests from dapps.

author: sky.cactus
content: For a batching invoker, the wallet will likely do something like prompt the user for each sub-transaction and ask them to "sign" them each individually and then the wallet will batch those and use an invoker it has been configured to use.

author: sky.cactus
content: Assuming the wallet does the right thing (security wise) the user is still having to "sign" per operation, same as today.

author: sky.cactus
content: Exceptions may be made for common patterns like "approve and call" or "router free Uniswap swap", where the wallet has native understanding of the pattern and asks the user for one consolidated transaction with a custom UI for the whole interaction.

author: samwilsn
content: Every specialized invoker will probably need an ERC, and similarly specialized wallet support.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think an ERC is necessary for this (standardization doesn't provide value here since it isn't a many-to-many relationship).

author: sky.cactus
content: However, I agree that invokers need specialized wallet support.
